WILLIAM D. WALSH is not a man to hold a grudge. In 1947, his first year at Fordham University, he was cut from the football team by the freshman coach, Vince Lombardi.

Last week, the university announced that Mr. Walsh, a trustee and venture capitalist who lives in Atherton, Calif., is giving $500,000 to improve the athletic center at the university's Rose Hill campus in the Bronx.
''I am the chairman of the subcommittee on athletics, and when I walked through the facilities, it was clear that something needed to be done,'' Mr. Walsh said.

He is also donating $10 million for a library, in the final stages of construction in the Bronx. It will be named the Walsh Library, and Mr. Walsh speculated, ''Students of the future will wonder who that was.''

Mr. Walsh, who graduated from Fordham in 1951, said: ''Fordham is a school that can be characterized as educating a great number of America's first-generation children. Like so many others, I was there when my family had no excess cash, and I worked as a theater barker and a hospital oxygen technician.''
